ment of the planet in "Justice League," Nary an award show
goes by without a star or several goes by without a star or several
begging viewers to take envibegging viewers to ta
ronment-saving action. So it was startling when the
weather-focused "Twisters" ar-weather-focused "Twisters" arrived from Universal Pictures this
month with no mention of climate change at all. If ever there was a perfect vehicle to carry Holly-
wood's progressive climate change messaging-abig-budget
movie about people caught in movie about people caught in
worsening storm patterns - wasn't this it?
Apparently not. Movies should not be about "preaching a mes
age," Lee Isaac Chung, who directed "Twisters," said in a prerelease interview that served as a dog whistle to conservative ticket buyers.
Trend spotting in cinema is hazardous pursuit. Sometimes a movie is just a movie. "Twisters," however, is emblematic of a clear
shift in Hollywood: After a period of openly using movies to display progressive values, sometimes
